name: More Interesting Word Origins Online Quiz | Quotes | 10 Questions

questions.text: Many people know that Levi jeans are named after the merchant, Levi Strauss. How did he popularize his product?
questions.correct: With prospectors, during the California Gold Rush
options: With soldiers during the American Revolution
With soldiers during the Civil War
questions.explanation:
With prospectors, during the California Gold Rush.

	It was during the Gold Rush of the 1840s and 1850s that Levi delivered the goods.

questions.text: Many people are likened to 'Falstaff', one of Shakespeare's better known characters. In which of these plays does he appear?
questions.correct: Henry IV, Parts I and II
questions.explanation:
Henry IV, Parts I and II.

	This is one of Shakespeare's best known characters and is widely recognized a literary 'type' and has given rise to the adjective "Falstaffian" - overweight, self-indulgent and given to bragging. He also appears in the "Merry Wives of Windsor".

questions.text: We sometimes speak of things that are done 'according to Hoyle'. In what area was Hoyle an expert?
questions.explanation:
Cards.

	He wrote books on the subject. The boxing expert was the Marquis of Queensberry.

questions.text: A 'malapropism' is a word that derives from the literary character of Mrs. Malaprop. Who is the author that created this character?
questions.explanation:
Richard Brinsley Sheridan.

	From one of his plays, 'The Rivals'.

questions.text: How did Alzheimer's Disease get its name?
questions.correct: It's named after the doctor who described the condition
options: It's named after the hospital where the first diagnoses and treatments were made.
It's named after an early victim of the disease
It's named after the region in which the condition was first described
questions.explanation:
It's named after the doctor who described the condition.

	Dr Alzheimer, early in the 20th century.

questions.text: Which of these figures is NOT a literary creation?
questions.explanation:
Guy Fawkes.

	Guy Fawkes conspired against the Crown - and paid for it dearly. There is a Guy Fawkes Day in England. Mitty comes from Thurber, Sherlock Holmes was created by Arthur Conan Doyle, and Tarzan was created by Edgar Rice Burroughs.

questions.text: Which of these common words and phrases owes its origin to an American Indian name?
questions.explanation:
Tammany Hall.

	Tammany - and it has different spellings - was an Indian chief.  Macadamia is derived from a chap named Macadam, and Jekyll and Hyde from R.L. Stevenson. [Cymruambyth has added:  Thespian can be found in literature, it actually derives from two sources - one is Thespis of Icaria (c 600 BCE), traditionally held to be the father of Greek tragedy - which is why actors are referred to as thespians - and the second is the town of Thespia, a town at the foot of Mount Helikon in Greece, where there was a shrine to the Muses].

questions.text: Which of these characters is NOT a mythological creation?
questions.explanation:
Pompadour.

	Madame Pompadour was a French aristocrat. Tantalus gives us 'tantalize', Camus wrote about the myth of Sisyphus, and 'Pandora's Box' is a familiar story.

questions.text: 'Casanova' and 'Lothario' are commonly used to describe great lovers. Were they real - or fictional?
questions.correct: Casanova was real; Lothario was fictional
options: Lothario was real; Casanova was fictional
questions.explanation:
Casanova was real; Lothario was fictional.

	Don't ask me about Don Juan

questions.text: The item known as 'knickers' is a shortened form of the word 'knickerbockers'. Which author used this word as a pen name?
questions.explanation:
Washington Irving.

	'History of New York' by Diedrich Knickerbocker.
